The virtues of the Buddha are permanence, bliss, self, and purity, which are based on the one mind.
By concentrating on the one qi, one attains softness; by cultivating the one mind, one achieves the Way.

The mind is vast, empty, wondrous, pure, radiant, and spiritually bright. It does not go or come, yet mysteriously penetrates the three periods of time. It is neither within nor without, yet penetrates the ten directions.
It does not perish or arise, so how can the four mountains harm it?
It is apart from nature and characteristics, so how can the five colors blind it?
Dwelling in the current of birth and death, the unique jewel shines in the vast ocean;
Sitting on the shore of nirvana, the solitary moon of cassia is bright in the blue sky.
How great it is!
All dharmas originate from it.
All dharmas are false and deceptive, arising from the convergence of conditions.
The dharma of arising is originally non-existent, all is consciousness only.
Consciousness is like an illusion or dream, it is just the one mind.
The mind is tranquil yet knowing, called perfect enlightenment, pervading and pure, not allowing anything else in the middle.
Therefore, its virtues and functions are boundless, all having the same nature.
Nature arises as characteristics, the objective realm and wisdom are distinct.
Characteristics merge with nature, body and mind are vast and still.
Compared to the ocean seal, surpassing the great void, vast and bright, it stands out beyond the realm of thought.
Our Buddha realized this, and had compassion for beings who were deluded about it. He sighed in wonder twice, and thought of the great matter three times.
